bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to John J. Moran, February 28, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg informs Moran that a series of paintings entitled "Pioneers of American Medicine" is planned. Moran will receive copies of the first two paintings, produced by Cornwell. Kellogg requests a photograph of Moran taken around the year 1900.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to John J. Moran, February 28, 1941
div1.opener:
Dr. Hench
EXECUTIVE
February 28, 1941.
Mr. John J. Moran
Sunoco Oil Company
Avenida Menocal 455-457
Havana, Cuba
Dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
You may have read something in the Havana papers about the series of
paintings which is now being done by Mr. Dean Cornwell for my firm, John
Wyeth & Brother Inc. of Philadelphia. It just happens that Mr. Cornwell
and I were in Havana during the time that you were in Pennsylvania
attending the dedication of the Lazear Memorial Hall at Washington and
Jefferson University. While in Cuba for two weeks, Mr. Cornwell and
I attempted to get as much of the story on what happened during the in-
vestigation of yellow fever back in 1900 as was possible from the Cubans,
but fortunately, Dr. P.F. Hench of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.
wrote us a few weeks ago and since that time we have had several conver-
sations and considerable correspondence with him.

Yesterday I placed copies of the first two paintings in the series
“Pioneers of American Medicine” in the mail for you and they will arrive
under separate cover at about the time this letter should be received.
I did this merely to let you know more about the project. Dr. Hench
has suggested that you may have additional information which will be of
value to us in getting ready for this painting. At the moment I have no
particular questions to ask you other than this: Have you a photograph
of yourself taken anywhere near the year 1900? We plan to put both you
and Mr. Kissinger in the painting along with the Reed Yellow Fever
Board and others who took an active part in the experiment. If you
have such a photograph, even though it may have been taken two or
three years earlier or up to ten years later it would be of considerable
value. We have a number of contemporary photographs of yourself but
one taken at an early age would be helpful. You may be assured that
it would be returned to you promptly and in good condition, as we would
only wish to have a photographic copy made.
div1.closer:
Cordially yours, George A. Kellogg
Advertising Director
John Wyeth & Brother Inc. GAK/ecs
